Key Arguments: The text outlines a system of accountability for the king and his officers, ensuring they adhere to the granted liberties and peace.
It establishes a council of twenty-five barons to oversee and enforce these liberties.
The barons have the authority to take corrective actions if the king or his officers violate the terms.
The system includes a mechanism for replacing barons who can no longer serve.
Decisions by the barons are made by majority vote if there is disagreement or absence among them.
Notable Quotes: We have granted all these concessions, desirous that they should enjoy them in complete and firm endurance forever.

The barons choose five and twenty barons of the kingdom, whomsoever they will, who shall be bound with all their might, to observe and hold, and cause to be observed, the peace and liberties we have granted and confirmed to them.

If we shall not have corrected the transgression... the four barons aforesaid shall refer that matter to the rest of the five and twenty barons, and those five and twenty barons shall, together with the community of the whole realm, distrain and distress us in all possible ways.
